items.title: NHS doctor suspended over alleged antisemitic social media posts
items.standfirst: Rahmeh Aladwan barred from practising for 15 months pending inquiry amid claims she ‘celebrated terrorist acts’An NHS doctor accused of antisemitism has been suspended for 15 months pending an investigation, the Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service (MPTS) in the UK has ruled.The General Medical Council (GMC) is investigating Dr Rahmeh Aladwan over posts and comments made across various social media platforms after several complaints, including from the Jewish Medical Association UK and the Campaign Against Antisemitism. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Severe asthma can be controlled by a monthly injection, trial finds
clusters.neutral_headline: Monthly injection controls severe asthma, trial finds

items.title: Severe asthma can be controlled by a monthly injection, trial finds
items.standfirst: Tezepelumab treatment may mean asthmatics for whom inhalers are ineffective can reduce or stop taking steroidsA monthly injection could allow people with severe asthma to stop taking daily steroid tablets, a clinical trial has found.More than 260 million people are thought to have asthma worldwide. While most can control their asthma with inhalers to treat immediate symptoms and preventive ones to reduce inflammation, those with the most severe asthma often take daily doses of oral corticosteroids as well. Continue reading...
items.content: Tezepelumab treatment may mean asthmatics for whom inhalers are ineffective can reduce or stop taking steroidsA monthly injection could allow people with severe asthma to stop taking daily steroid tablets, a clinical trial has found.More than 260 million people are thought to have asthma worldwide. While most can control their asthma with inhalers to treat immediate symptoms and preventive ones to reduce inflammation, those with the most severe asthma often take daily doses of oral corticosteroids as well. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A clinical trial found a monthly injection can control severe asthma.
The treatment is called tezepelumab.
It may allow patients to reduce or stop steroid use.
Over 260 million people worldwide have asthma.
Inhalers are often ineffective for severe asthma sufferers.

clusters.title: Experts warn of ‘global crisis’ as number of women in prison nears one million
clusters.neutral_headline: Experts warn of ‘global crisis’ as number of women in prison nears one million

items.title: Experts warn of ‘global crisis’ as number of women in prison nears one million
items.standfirst: Number of women incarcerated around the world rising at nearly three times the rate of men, with female prisoners often subjected to sexual violence and forced labourExplainer: How many women are in prison and on death row around the world? – in chartsUp to a million women worldwide are facing sexual violence and forced labour in prisons, where they are overlooked and forgotten, in what is being called a growing global crisis.The number of incarcerated women is rising much faster than men and is expected to surpass one million on current trends. While on average women account for between 2% and 9% of national prison populations, since 2000 the number imprisoned has grown by 57%, compared with a 22% increase in the men’s prison population. Continue reading...
items.content: Number of women incarcerated around the world rising at nearly three times the rate of men, with female prisoners often subjected to sexual violence and forced labourExplainer: How many women are in prison and on death row around the world? – in chartsUp to a million women worldwide are facing sexual violence and forced labour in prisons, where they are overlooked and forgotten, in what is being called a growing global crisis.The number of incarcerated women is rising much faster than men and is expected to surpass one million on current trends. While on average women account for between 2% and 9% of national prison populations, since 2000 the number imprisoned has grown by 57%, compared with a 22% increase in the men’s prison population. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The number of incarcerated women is rising rapidly worldwide.
The increase is nearly three times the rate of men.
Female prisoners often face sexual violence and forced labor.
The number of women imprisoned is expected to exceed one million.
The growth in female incarceration has been significant since 2000.

items.title: System failed our daughter, say parents, as NHS trust fined £200,000 over death
items.standfirst: Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, who had mental health problems, absconded from a ward and killed herself shortly afterwardsA girl who killed herself when she absconded from 24-hour clinical supervision was failed by a system that was meant to protect her, her parents have said, after the NHS trust involved was fined over the avoidable death.Ellame Ford-Dunn, 16, who suffered with severe mental health problems, died on 20 March 2022, minutes after leaving the Bluefin acute children’s ward in Worthing hospital, part of University hospitals Sussex NHS trust (UHSussex). Continue reading...

Continue reading...

clusters.title: Shortfall in return on investment in health | Brief letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Shortfall in return on investment in health

items.title: Shortfall in return on investment in health | Brief letters
items.standfirst: Great Western Park health centre | Cricket headlines | UK emissions | Quick Crossword | Air guitarLord Hutton writes of the NHS health centres that have been built thanks to private finance (Letters, 23 November). In Didcot we’ve been waiting more than 10 years for the Great Western Park health centre. The return on investment required by the developer is greater than the NHS will reimburse. The local integrated care board fears that at that cost they’ll not get a GP practice to take on the health centre.Cllr Sarah JamesVale of White Horse district council• Congratulations on the print-edition headline “Lights, Canberra, no action”, about England’s beaten cricketers not playing in the Australian capital (24 November). It reminded me of my all-time favourite in the Guardian when Zaheer Abbas began the county cricket season in 1981 by scoring 1,000 runs in one month: “Happy days Zaheer again”. Genius.Mark GarrodPotters Bar, Hertfordshire Continue reading...
items.content: Great Western Park health centre | Cricket headlines | UK emissions | Quick Crossword | Air guitarLord Hutton writes of the NHS health centres that have been built thanks to private finance (Letters, 23 November). In Didcot we’ve been waiting more than 10 years for the Great Western Park health centre. The return on investment required by the developer is greater than the NHS will reimburse. The local integrated care board fears that at that cost they’ll not get a GP practice to take on the health centre.Cllr Sarah JamesVale of White Horse district council• Congratulations on the print-edition headline “Lights, Canberra, no action”, about England’s beaten cricketers not playing in the Australian capital (24 November). It reminded me of my all-time favourite in the Guardian when Zaheer Abbas began the county cricket season in 1981 by scoring 1,000 runs in one month: “Happy days Zaheer again”. Genius.Mark GarrodPotters Bar, Hertfordshire Continue reading...

ai_summary: A health center in Didcot has been delayed over ten years.
The return on investment demanded by the developer is too high.
The local integrated care board fears a GP practice won't take it.
A letter writer congratulates a headline about cricket.
The letter writer also shares a favorite Guardian headline.

clusters.title: ‘My mother had dementia but beautiful things unfolded’: Cheryle St Onge’s best photograph
clusters.neutral_headline: ‘My mother had dementia but beautiful things unfolded’: Cheryle St Onge’s best photograph

items.title: ‘My mother had dementia but beautiful things unfolded’: Cheryle St Onge’s best photograph
items.standfirst: ‘She wasn’t very fond of Skipper, our jack russell, who loved the hose. But they were dancing together – two beings in the afternoon sunlight, having their own conversation’I am an only child. My father was killed in a car accident when I was 14 and my mother was 47. We were really tightly bonded after that. She worked at a university and was an artist: she painted and carved birds. She was a wonderful person, who lit up a room and was someone everyone wanted to be around. She was very giving.Later in life, she developed dementia. I left my teaching position to stay home and look after her. She was very active – she would go outside and rip up bulbs, put the horses in the wrong stalls. It was very stressful to come home – I would enter the driveway and think: “Oh my word!” Continue reading...
items.content: ‘She wasn’t very fond of Skipper, our jack russell, who loved the hose. But they were dancing together – two beings in the afternoon sunlight, having their own conversation’I am an only child. My father was killed in a car accident when I was 14 and my mother was 47. We were really tightly bonded after that. She worked at a university and was an artist: she painted and carved birds. She was a wonderful person, who lit up a room and was someone everyone wanted to be around. She was very giving.Later in life, she developed dementia. I left my teaching position to stay home and look after her. She was very active – she would go outside and rip up bulbs, put the horses in the wrong stalls. It was very stressful to come home – I would enter the driveway and think: “Oh my word!” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The article features a photograph of a woman with dementia.
The woman's daughter cared for her.
The mother was an artist and worked at a university.
The daughter left her job to care for her mother.
The photograph captures a moment of connection.

clusters.title: Vitamin supplements with high levels of B6 will be removed from general sale in Australia – here’s what you need to know
clusters.neutral_headline: Vitamin supplements with high levels of B6 will be removed from general sale in Australia – here’s what you need to know

items.title: Vitamin supplements with high levels of B6 will be removed from general sale in Australia – here’s what you need to know
items.standfirst: As the Therapeutic Goods Administration takes action, what should you do until the rules come into force?Australia’s drug regulator has ordered that supplements with high levels of vitamin B6 be removed from general sale in response to hundreds of reports of nerve damage and other side-effects linked to long-term use.From June 2027 any vitamin B6 product containing more than 50mg in each recommended daily dose will be moved behind the pharmacy counter. The recommended dietary intake of vitamin B6 for a healthy adult is just 1.3mg to 1.7mg a day. Continue reading...
items.content: As the Therapeutic Goods Administration takes action, what should you do until the rules come into force?Australia’s drug regulator has ordered that supplements with high levels of vitamin B6 be removed from general sale in response to hundreds of reports of nerve damage and other side-effects linked to long-term use.From June 2027 any vitamin B6 product containing more than 50mg in each recommended daily dose will be moved behind the pharmacy counter. The recommended dietary intake of vitamin B6 for a healthy adult is just 1.3mg to 1.7mg a day. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Australia is removing high-dose vitamin B6 supplements from sale.
The move follows reports of nerve damage and side effects.
Products with over 50mg per dose will be affected.
The change will take effect from June 2027.
The recommended daily intake is 1.3 to 1.7mg.

clusters.title: UK politics: No 10 says no final decisions after leak reveals jury trials might be scrapped except for alleged rapists and killers – as it happened
clusters.neutral_headline: UK politics: No 10 says no final decisions after leak reveals jury trials might be scrapped except for alleged rapists and killers – as it happened

items.title: UK politics: No 10 says no final decisions after leak reveals jury trials might be scrapped except for alleged rapists and killers – as it happened
items.standfirst: Downing Street does not deny that justice secretary, David Lammy, is considering scrapping juries for most trialsJohn McFall is standing down early as Lord Speaker in the House of Lords so that he can care for his wife, Joan, who has was Parkinson’s. According to Sam Blewett and Bethany Dawson in their London Playbook briefing for Politico, the main candidates to replace him are Michael Forsyth, a rightwing Scottish secretary in the final two years of the John Major government, and Deborah Bull, a crossbencher and former Royal Opera House creative director. They reports:Labour isn’t expected to put forward a candidate as McFall’s previous political affiliation means it’s seen as another party’s turn to rule the roost, Noah [Keate] writes in to say. Forsyth has garnered support from some Labour grandees who like his traditional approach and aversion to modernization while Bull has being promoted by some female peers keen for a woman to take charge. One Tory peer described Forsyth as a “political animal” who may struggle to encourage a consensus across the chamber. A list of candidates’ register of interests and election addresses (up to 300 words) will be emailed to all peers on Dec. 1. Watch your inboxes!Transport secretary Heidi Alexander rejected a rival proposal from Arora Group, saying Heathrow’s own plans were “the most credible and deliverable option”.The Heathrow proposals involve building a 3,500-metre runway and require a new M25 tunnel and bridges to be built 130 metres west of the existing motorway.Following a comparative assessment of the remaining proposals for Heathrow expansion, the government’s view is that the Northwest runway scheme brought forward by Heathrow Airport Limited offers the most credible and deliverable option, principally due to the relative maturity of its proposal, the comparative level of confidence in the feasibility and resilience of its surface access plans, and the stronger comfort it provides in relation to the efficient, resilient and sustainable operations of the airport over the long-term.The HAL scheme is considered comparatively more mature in its approach to road infrastructure. While the HAL scheme requires major works to the M25, assessment indicates that the HWL scheme would also have a considerable impact on the M25. Continue reading...
items.content: Downing Street does not deny that justice secretary, David Lammy, is considering scrapping juries for most trialsJohn McFall is standing down early as Lord Speaker in the House of Lords so that he can care for his wife, Joan, who has was Parkinson’s. According to Sam Blewett and Bethany Dawson in their London Playbook briefing for Politico, the main candidates to replace him are Michael Forsyth, a rightwing Scottish secretary in the final two years of the John Major government, and Deborah Bull, a crossbencher and former Royal Opera House creative director. They reports:Labour isn’t expected to put forward a candidate as McFall’s previous political affiliation means it’s seen as another party’s turn to rule the roost, Noah [Keate] writes in to say. Forsyth has garnered support from some Labour grandees who like his traditional approach and aversion to modernization while Bull has being promoted by some female peers keen for a woman to take charge. One Tory peer described Forsyth as a “political animal” who may struggle to encourage a consensus across the chamber. A list of candidates’ register of interests and election addresses (up to 300 words) will be emailed to all peers on Dec. 1. Watch your inboxes!Transport secretary Heidi Alexander rejected a rival proposal from Arora Group, saying Heathrow’s own plans were “the most credible and deliverable option”.The Heathrow proposals involve building a 3,500-metre runway and require a new M25 tunnel and bridges to be built 130 metres west of the existing motorway.Following a comparative assessment of the remaining proposals for Heathrow expansion, the government’s view is that the Northwest runway scheme brought forward by Heathrow Airport Limited offers the most credible and deliverable option, principally due to the relative maturity of its proposal, the comparative level of confidence in the feasibility and resilience of its surface access plans, and the stronger comfort it provides in relation to the efficient, resilient and sustainable operations of the airport over the long-term.The HAL scheme is considered comparatively more mature in its approach to road infrastructure. While the HAL scheme requires major works to the M25, assessment indicates that the HWL scheme would also have a considerable impact on the M25. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Downing Street denies final decisions on jury trials.
Justice Secretary is considering scrapping juries for most trials.
John McFall is stepping down as Lord Speaker.
Candidates to replace him include Michael Forsyth and Deborah Bull.
Heathrow's runway plans are considered the most credible.

clusters.title: Covid inquiry lays bare unforgivable failures of Boris Johnson’s government | Letters
clusters.neutral_headline: Covid inquiry lays bare unforgivable failures of Boris Johnson’s government | Letters: Readers respond to the official report on the handling of the pandemic

items.title: Covid inquiry lays bare unforgivable failures of Boris Johnson’s government | Letters
items.standfirst: Readers respond to the official report on the handling of the pandemicRe your report (‘Too little, too late’: damning report condemns UK’s Covid response, 20 November), shortly after lockdown began, my family lost an aunt and uncle within an hour of each other to Covid in different hospitals in Manchester. Their son was in a third in A&E, also with Covid, but survived. Six months later my father, who was in hospital recuperating from major surgery, was rushed out of the building late at night because of a fear of Covid on the ward. Within two weeks, he died of Covid. On the day he died, my mother tested positive and spent the next two weeks grieving in isolation. I could not visit as I lived 200 miles away and respected the travel ban.At his funeral, we followed the rules, so a very small number of people could attend. My father was such a part of the local community that people lined the roads around the cemetery, everyone respecting social distancing. I could not hug my mother at the funeral because we were not in the same bubble. Continue reading...
items.content: Readers respond to the official report on the handling of the pandemicRe your report (‘Too little, too late’: damning report condemns UK’s Covid response, 20 November), shortly after lockdown began, my family lost an aunt and uncle within an hour of each other to Covid in different hospitals in Manchester. Their son was in a third in A&E, also with Covid, but survived. Six months later my father, who was in hospital recuperating from major surgery, was rushed out of the building late at night because of a fear of Covid on the ward. Within two weeks, he died of Covid. On the day he died, my mother tested positive and spent the next two weeks grieving in isolation. I could not visit as I lived 200 miles away and respected the travel ban.At his funeral, we followed the rules, so a very small number of people could attend. My father was such a part of the local community that people lined the roads around the cemetery, everyone respecting social distancing. I could not hug my mother at the funeral because we were not in the same bubble. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A reader's family lost relatives to COVID-19 in different hospitals during the pandemic.
Another reader's father died of COVID-19 after being moved from a hospital ward.
The reader's mother tested positive and isolated while grieving.
The reader could not attend the funeral due to travel restrictions.
The funeral had a small attendance with people lining the roads.

clusters.title: I got an epidural for all three of my births – none of them worked as expected
clusters.neutral_headline: I got an epidural for all three of my births – none of them worked as expected: Here’s what you should know before getting an epidural – and why it might not provide full pain relief as expected

items.title: I got an epidural for all three of my births – none of them worked as expected
items.standfirst: Here’s what you should know before getting an epidural – and why it might not provide full pain relief as expectedThe first time I got an epidural, it was too late.I’d heard it was best to wait, for fear the medication would run out mid-labor (I later found out this is a myth). So I gritted my teeth through hours of contractions, and when I finally told the nurses I was ready, the anesthesiologist was with another patient. Continue reading...
items.content: Here’s what you should know before getting an epidural – and why it might not provide full pain relief as expectedThe first time I got an epidural, it was too late.I’d heard it was best to wait, for fear the medication would run out mid-labor (I later found out this is a myth). So I gritted my teeth through hours of contractions, and when I finally told the nurses I was ready, the anesthesiologist was with another patient. Continue reading...

ai_summary: The author's first epidural was administered too late in labor.
The author waited due to a misconception about medication running out.
The anesthesiologist was unavailable when the author was ready.
The author experienced hours of contractions before the epidural.
The article discusses potential issues with epidural effectiveness.

clusters.title: The majority of doctors supported the recent strike. So why did the Department of Health suggest the opposite? | Peter Kellner
clusters.neutral_headline: Poll Data Questioned Regarding Doctors' Strike Support

items.title: The majority of doctors supported the recent strike. So why did the Department of Health suggest the opposite? | Peter Kellner
items.standfirst: It would seem that poll data was cherrypicked and then used to brief the Times. Such distortion of facts from a public body should alarm us allThe latest strike by resident doctors began on Friday 14 November. That morning, the headline of the lead story on the front page of the Times proclaimed: “Five days of NHS strikes opposed by most doctors”.The story began: “Most junior doctors do not support Friday’s strike, a poll has revealed as Wes Streeting attacked the British Medical Association for going ‘against the wishes’ of its members.” The trouble is that the poll showed no such thing.Peter Kellner is a former president of YouGovDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...
items.content: It would seem that poll data was cherrypicked and then used to brief the Times. Such distortion of facts from a public body should alarm us allThe latest strike by resident doctors began on Friday 14 November. That morning, the headline of the lead story on the front page of the Times proclaimed: “Five days of NHS strikes opposed by most doctors”.The story began: “Most junior doctors do not support Friday’s strike, a poll has revealed as Wes Streeting attacked the British Medical Association for going ‘against the wishes’ of its members.” The trouble is that the poll showed no such thing.Peter Kellner is a former president of YouGovDo you have an opinion on the issues raised in this article? If you would like to submit a response of up to 300 words by email to be considered for publication in our letters section, please click here. Continue reading...

ai_summary: A recent strike by resident doctors began on Friday, November 14th.
The Times newspaper reported most doctors opposed the strike based on a poll.
The poll results did not support the Times' headline claim.
The article criticizes the Department of Health's use of poll data.
Peter Kellner, former president of YouGov, wrote the article.

The guidance led to fines and surprise bills for thousands.
Liz Sayce, a former charity boss, conducted the review.
The review addresses issues related to carer support.
The announcement follows the release of a damning report.

items.content: Milkshakes and lattes to be included in UK sugar tax scheme for the first time.

ai_summary: Milkshakes and lattes will be included in the UK sugar tax.
This is the first time milk-based drinks will be taxed.
The sugar tax aims to reduce sugar consumption.
The tax applies to drinks with high sugar content.
The change is part of the UK sugar tax scheme.

clusters.title: Does methylene blue really have wellness benefits or will it just leave you with the blues? | Antiviral
clusters.neutral_headline: Does methylene blue really have wellness benefits or will it just leave you with the blues? | Antiviral: The fabric dye is popular in wellness circles, with a laundry list of claimed benefits – but it also carries serious risks

items.title: Does methylene blue really have wellness benefits or will it just leave you with the blues? | Antiviral
items.standfirst: The fabric dye is popular in wellness circles, with a laundry list of claimed benefits – but it also carries serious risksRead more in the Antiviral seriesA week before he was sworn in as secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services in February, a video of anti-vaccination conspiracy theorist Robert F Kennedy Jr went viral.In it, Kennedy, who has frequently promoted debunked health claims, is seen squirting inky blue liquid into a drinking glass. The substance was widely speculated to be a dye called methylene blue, though Kennedy has not publicly commented on it. Continue reading...
items.content: The fabric dye is popular in wellness circles, with a laundry list of claimed benefits – but it also carries serious risksRead more in the Antiviral seriesA week before he was sworn in as secretary of the US Department of Health and Human Services in February, a video of anti-vaccination conspiracy theorist Robert F Kennedy Jr went viral.In it, Kennedy, who has frequently promoted debunked health claims, is seen squirting inky blue liquid into a drinking glass. The substance was widely speculated to be a dye called methylene blue, though Kennedy has not publicly commented on it. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Methylene blue is popular in wellness circles, with many claimed benefits.
The dye carries potential serious risks for users.
A video of Robert F Kennedy Jr. went viral using the dye.
Kennedy has promoted debunked health claims in the past.
Kennedy was seen squirting the blue liquid into a glass.
